Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
FOR CWL ONLY
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Jessica VandenHeuvel, Area Manager, at 616-204-6992.

ALLEGATION:
On 3/23/22, a youth was restrained by staff. There are concerns that the restraint
was unwarranted and may have resulted in bruising on the upper arms.
INVESTIGATION:
On March 28, 2022, a special investigation was initiated into the allegation described
above. The investigation was conducted jointly with a MDHHS Worker. Staff and
youth were interviewed. Documents were reviewed as well as a video recording of
the incident. What follows is information obtained from the aforementioned sources.
On March 29, 2022, the agency Chief Administrator was informed that a special
investigation had been initiated. The agency had self-reported the incident.
2

Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on March 31, 2022, in
collaboration with the MDHHS Worker. Youth A reported that on the day of the
incident she was sitting in the main room on a couch, using a tack to try and pierce
her nose. Youth A reported Staff 1 and Staff 2 confronted her asking that she give
them the tack. Youth A reported that she gave them the tack but not the nose ring as
she put the nose ring into her pants pocket. Youth A reported Staff 1 and Staff 2
continued to ask her to give them the nose ring, but she refused. Youth A reported
Staff 3 arrived and asked her to give staff the nose ring. Youth A reported she took
off her shirt as she did not want Staff 4 to touch her, and she wanted him to leave
the room. Youth A reported when she continued to refuse to give staff the nose ring
Staff 2 and Staff 3 took hold of her arms, and she was pulled off the couch. Youth A
reported she was fighting the restraint. Youth A reported Staff 2 and Staff 3 were
holding her arms and Staff 4 was holding her legs. Youth A reported she calmed
down enough that staff released her from the restraint, and she went towards the
television as she wanted to pull it down from the wall. Youth A reported staff were
blocking her from grabbing the television. She walked away and said she was
leaving as she wanted to go to the sensory room to take a time out. Youth A
reported that Staff 1 and Staff 2 then placed her in an upper torso restraint, and she
was soon released.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on March 31, 2022, in
collaboration with the MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 reported she is a Safety and
Security 1. Staff 1 reported on the day of the incident Youth A was sitting on a couch
in the living room and Youth B was helping Youth A to pierce her nose. Staff 1
reported at one point Youth A was seen trying to push something into her nose and
was asked by staff what she was doing. Staff 1 reported Youth A became defensive
but gave Staff 2 a tack. Staff 1 reported soon after she observed Youth A trying to
again push something into her nose. Staff 1 reported she and Staff 2 asked Youth A
to give them the object she was using to pierce with when Staff 3 arrived. Staff 1
reported Youth A refused. Staff 2 and Staff 3 went into an escort hold as they
wanted to transport Youth A to the sensory room. Staff 1 reported Youth A began to
fight the hold and slid off the couch and a restraint was started. Staff 2 and Staff 3
initiated the restraint and Staff 4 assisted by holding Youth A’s legs. Staff 1 reported
at one point she relieved Staff 3 from the restraint. Staff 1 reported when Youth A
was released from the hold Youth A stated she was going to smash the house
television. Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 3 blocked Youth A from grabbing the television.
Staff 1 reported Youth A began making threats that she was going to run out the
door and AWOL. Staff 1 reported she and Staff 2 placed Youth A into a standing
upper torso restraint and was released when she de-escalated.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on March 31, 2022, in
collaboration with the MDHHS Worker. Staff 2 is an agency Shift Supervisor. Staff
2 reported Youth A was attempting to pierce her nose and when asked, Youth A
gave her the tack. Staff 2 reported soon after Staff 1 told her that Youth A again
attempted to pierce her nose with an object. Staff 2 reported Youth A was refused to
give her the object and she called Staff 3 for assistance. Staff 2 reported when Staff
3

3 arrived she and Staff 3 attempted a hook transport. Youth A began to fight the hold
and she was placed in a supine restraint. Staff 2 reported Staff 1 managed to
retrieve a nose ring out of the pocket of Youth A. Staff 2 reported upon releasing
Youth A she attempted to walk to the television but was blocked by staff. Staff 2
reported Youth A began to walk away saying she was leaving so she was placed in
a standing upper torso restraint. Staff 2 reported the initial escort hold was an
attempt to get control of Youth A’s arms so another staff could get the nose ring out
of the pants pocket of Youth A.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on March 31, 2022, in
collaboration with the MDHHS Worker. Staff 3 is the agency Unit Manager. Staff 3
reported Staff 2 had called her for assistance as Youth A was attempting to pierce
her nose with an object and would not give staff the object. Staff 3 reported she
wanted to do a hook transport to remove Youth A from an area where other youth
could observe the incident and possibly become escalated. Staff 3 reported that they
wanted to transport Youth A to the sensory room. Staff 3 reported when she and
Staff 2 took hold of Youth A’s arm she began to fight the hold and slid off the couch.
She was then placed in a supine restraint. Staff 3 reported when Youth A was
released, she walked towards the television threatening to break it and staff blocked
her from doing so. Staff 3 reported Youth A stated she was leaving and was
threatening to go AWOL and was place in a standing upper torso restraint.
Staff 4 was interviewed face to face at the facility on March 31, 2022, in
collaboration with the MDHHS Worker. Staff 4 is a Lead Staff. Staff 4 reported he
assisted with the supine restraint and when Youth A was released, she started
walking towards the television threatening to break it. Staff 4 reported Youth A was
prevented from getting to the television and then restrained again as she was
threatening to go AWOL.
Staff 5 was interviewed face to face at the facility on March 31, 2022, in
collaboration with the MDHHS Worker. Staff 5 is the Medical Technician for the
agency. Staff 5 reported she examined Youth A after the incident and found “slight
bruising on upper arms” of Youth A. Staff 5 reported the bruises were “pink and a
light purple”. Staff 5 reported Youth A did not require any medical attention.
Video Reviewed:
Video footage of March 23, 2022 was reviewed at the facility on March 31,
2022. The video footage was reviewed in collaboration with the MDHHS
Worker. The video establishes the following. Youth A is sitting on a couch and Staff
1 and Staff 2 are standing in front of her. Youth A takes off her shirt. Staff 3 arrives
and Staff 3 and Staff 2 take hold of Youth A’s arms. Youth A begins to struggle and
slides off the couch and is placed in a supine restraint. Staff 2 and Staff 3 are
holding the arms of Youth A while Staff 4 and Staff 1 are holding the legs of Youth A.
Staff 1 releases and at one point relieves Staff 3. Youth A is seen trying to get up
and is fighting the hold. Youth A is released after approximately 17 minutes. Youth A
then is seen to move towards the television and staff are blocking her from access to
4

the television. Youth A begins to walk towards the foyer area and Staff 1 and Staff 2
conduct a standing upper torso. Youth A is then released after approximately 4
minutes.
The MDHHS Worker did not have findings.
Documents Reviewed:
 Staff 1’s personnel file. There was no disciplinary record and Staff 1 is current
with Safe Crises Management (SCM) training.
 Staff 2’s personnel file contained 1 disciplinary action in 2021 for not
completing rounds and Staff 2 is current with SCM training.
 Staff 3’s personnel file contained a disciplinary action in 2020 for providing a
pregnancy test to a youth. Staff 3 is current with SCM training.
 Staff 4’s personnel file did not contain any disciplinary action and Staff 4 is
current with SCM training.
 Incident Report dated March 23, 2022, was reviewed and is consistent with
the interviews of Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 3, and Staff 4 and notes that Youth A
did not receive injuries except for bruising on her upper right arm.
 MISACWIS Case File: The file of Youth A was reviewed.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4159 Resident restraint.
(4) The written policy shall only permit the licensee to
restrain a child for the following circumstances:
(a) To prevent injury to the child, self-injury, or injury to
others.
(b) As a precaution against escape or truancy.
(c) When there is serious destruction of property that
places a child or others at serious threat of violence or
injury if no intervention occurs.
ANALYSIS: The facility was found in noncompliance as Staff 2 and Staff 3
initiated a restraint when Youth A was not self-harming, harming
others, truanting, or engaging in serious destruction of property.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
SIR 2022C0114023, CAP approval dated 4/15/22
